title: Join CINAS
text:
CINAS operates on an open innovation model. We are looking for curious minds and strategic partners.






Important



 Special Call: Physics-Informed ML (Health and Nuclear)
We are specifically looking for researchers and students to join our new Physics-Informed Machine Learning line.
Areas of Interest:
Medical Imaging: Application of physical laws in image reconstruction.
Nuclear Technology: Inverse problems in neutron tomography.


For Students (Master’s and PhD)
Joining CINAS means working at the intersection of Computing and Radiation Sciences.
What you will develop:
Multilingual Computational Fluency: Mastery of Python, R, and C/C++.
Scientific Rigor: Deep understanding of radiation physics.
Innovation Vision: Ability to create solutions for real-world problems.






Note



Interested?
Send your CV (or Lattes) and a brief letter of intent to our contact email, mentioning which research line interests you most.


For Partners
We seek collaboration for technology validation and co-development.
What We Are Looking For Now
Academic Partners in PIML: Researchers interested in collaborating on the foundations of Physics-Informed ML.
Hospitals: Access to anonymized clinical data and clinical validation.
International Exchange: Research groups in Nuclear Digital Twin or Medical AI.

title: Who We Are
text:
Strategic Vision
CINAS consolidates a translational research initiative situated at the convergence of Advanced Computer Science and Radiation Sciences.
In a global scenario where digital transformation redefines scientific paradigms, we operate under the premise that the next frontier of nuclear and medical innovation will come from the intelligence extracted from data.






Expanding Frontiers: We are currently expanding our activities to incorporate Physics-Informed Machine Learning (PIML), actively seeking academic partners to consolidate this new methodology at IPEN.



Leadership





Mário O. de Menezes
Senior Researcher - IPEN/CNEN
Physicist with extensive experience in neutron imaging and scientific computing. Advises master’s students in the Nuclear Technology (USP) and Professional Master’s in Radiation Technology programs, leading projects that unite academia with professional practice.

title: Advanced Computing applied to Radiation Sciences
text:
Welcome to CINAS


Connecting Algorithms, Atoms, and Health.

The Research Group on Computing and AI in Nuclear and Health Sciences (CINAS) operates at the frontier of knowledge, bridging the gap between algorithmic development and critical applications in nuclear infrastructures and clinical environments.
Our mission is to develop methodologies that incorporate physical and biological domain knowledge into the architecture of intelligent models.
Learn more about us Our Research






Our Research Axes




 Digital Health
Innovation in diagnostic imaging and therapy. Highlight: Initiating studies in Physics-Informed ML for medical imaging, alongside Deep Learning and clinical validation.

Information management, quality, and processes. Data governance, ontologies, and Big Data analysis (DATASUS).

title: Our Research Lines
text:
The CINAS project portfolio is structured into three strategic axes, uniting scientific rigor with technological innovation.


1. Technological Innovation in Diagnosis and Therapy


 From Algorithm to Clinic
We investigate how algorithms can “see” what the human eye cannot, increasing diagnostic accuracy and therapeutic safety.
AI and Oncology: Deep Learning models for volumetric (3D) prostate segmentation and explainability models (XAI).
Federated Learning: Training models across multiple hospitals while preserving privacy (GDPR/LGPD).
Precision Radiotherapy: Machine Learning for automatic gamma index evaluation in treatment plans.
Technology Assessment: Comparative studies (e.g., Dual-Energy CT vs. MRI).







2. Information Management and Processes


 Structuring and Governance
We recognize that without organized data, there is no artificial intelligence. We act at the base of the knowledge pyramid.
Knowledge Engineering: Ontologies for nuclear domains and data governance (FAIR principles).
Public Health & Big Data: Data mining from DATASUS (e.g., mammography screening tracking).
Intelligent Search: Semantic solutions for Radiology Information Systems (RIS).
Quality Management: Performance indicators and biosafety manuals in Nuclear Medicine and Radiology.







3. Modeling and AI in Nuclear Facilities


 Physical-Digital Synergy
The “hard core” of our activities at IPEN, focused on the safety and efficiency of nuclear facilities.
Reactor Operation: Large Language Models (LLMs) as decision support systems for reactor operators.
New Front (Nuclear PIML): Application in neutron tomography.











Important



 New Transversal Front: Physics-Informed Machine Learning (PIML)
We are initiating advanced studies in PIML for two strategic applications, aiming to overcome the limitations of purely data-driven models by incorporating physical laws.


 Nuclear
Neutron Tomography: Resolution improvement and solving ill-posed inverse problems.


 Health
Medical Imaging: Low-dose tomographic reconstruction and artifact reduction.


Opportunity: We are looking for students (Master’s/PhD) and partner researchers interested in co-developing these lines from the ground up.
